title: 106_s2712
content: The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" may be cited as the short title for this Act. The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" aims to consolidate financial and performance management reports to eliminate duplication of effort, provide more useful information to Congress, the President, and the public, improve the quality of agency information, and enhance coordination and efficiency. The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" aims to improve agency financial and performance management information and enhance coordination and efficiency in reporting. The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" amends Chapter 35 of title 31, United States Code by adding a section on reports consolidation. The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" allows executive agencies to adjust the frequency and due dates of statutorily required reports with approval from the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. These reports can be consolidated into an annual report to be submitted to the President, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Congress within 150 days after the agency's fiscal year. This includes various agency-specific reports and other statutorily required reports. The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" allows executive agencies to adjust the frequency and due dates of statutorily required reports with approval from the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. These reports can be consolidated into an annual report to be submitted to the President, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Congress within 150 days after the agency's fiscal year. This includes various agency-specific reports and other statutorily required reports. The annual report of the Attorney General under section 522 of title 28 and any other statutorily required report pertaining to an agency's financial or performance management can be included if it enhances the usefulness of the reported information to decision makers and with consultation with relevant congressional committees. Reports under this act may be referred to as performance and accountability reports if they incorporate the agency's program performance report under section 1116. If the report does not incorporate the program performance report, it should contain a summary of the most significant portions of the agency's program performance report, including the agency's success in achieving key objectives. The agency's program performance report must include a statement from the inspector general on management challenges and progress, a transmittal letter from the agency head assessing data completeness and reliability. The assessment must identify any data inadequacies and actions to resolve them. A special rule allows for consolidated reports for fiscal years 2000 and 2001. Amendments relate to audited financial statements, including changes to reporting requirements. Section 3521(f) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to eliminate subsections (e) through (h). Section 1116(a) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to change the report due date to 150 days after the end of an agency's fiscal year, with a special rule for fiscal years 2000 and 2001 allowing reports to be submitted within 180 days. The agency head must assess the completeness and reliability of performance data in each program performance report. Any inadequacies must be described along with actions being taken to resolve them. If the report is included in a larger submission, different requirements apply.
